title: Workflows Guidebook
text:
Welcome! After reviewing the guidebook, please complete the following onboarding tasks:

Request access to Google chat space
Check that you have been added to the monthly meetings
Review previous running notes
Review guidebook
Review asar and stockplotr repositories

Feel free to reach out to any of the current members of the team with any additional questions.

title: Workflows Guidebook
text:
The project folder called “Steering Committee” can be found in your “Shared drives” folder in Google Drive. This folder contains important documents and resources related to the steering committee’s activities, including meeting notes, agendas, and other relevant materials.
The following folders are the most relevant to review for new members:

Call agenda/notes
Conference abstracts
Implementation plans
Manuscripts

Any new steering committee members are encouraged to review the content in this folder prior to their first meeting.

title: Workflows Guidebook
text:
Meeting Notes
Meeting notes from previous steering committee meetings can be found in a living Google document (viewable and editable by the steering committee and internal NOAA HQ team). These notes provide a record of discussions, decisions, and action items from past meetings.
Each meeting, a new section is added to the document with the date and agenda items discussed. Steering committee members are encouraged to review the notes from previous meetings to stay informed about ongoing discussions and initiatives. A member of the workflows team will set the agenda in these notes for each meeting and send any important materials in advance.

title: Workflows Guidebook
text:
Additional Documents
Over time, we have utilized Google docs to organize and draft important documents for the steering committee including:

Proposed outline for a fisheries stock assessment report template
Proposed tables and figures
Draft guidelines for a stock assessment report
and more found within the steering committee implementation plans folder

Each of these documents contains key processes that each steering committee member participated in and helped rationalize decisions made throughout the development of the project. New members are encouraged to review these documents to gain a deeper understanding of the committee’s work and contributions.

title: Meeting Schedule and Communication
text:
Meeting Schedule and Communication
The workflows steering committee meets virtually on the second Tuesday of each month at 3:30 PM Eastern Time. Meeting invitations and agendas are sent out in advance to all committee members. Meetings are based on need, so it is not uncommon during the development process when no feedback is needed to cancel the meeting.
During meetings, steering committee members are encouraged to use the raise hand feature to contribute to the discussion or utilize other Google meets features like reactions (i.e. thumbs up) or chat to add their input.
Communication with the steering committee is made through email, Google chat space, and GitHub discussions.


Meeting Planning
Meeting topics and agenda are planned up to one week in advance by the workflows team. The topics are contingent on need and any topics that might have come up throughout the month before the meeting.
Occasionally, a request to discuss a topic from an outside party may arise and, when relevant, it will be added to the agenda.
Steering committee members are encouraged to preview the agenda or add their own topics when the need arises.
The agenda and notes can be found in a living Google document (viewable and editable by the steering committee and internal NOAA HQ team).


Feedback Deadlines
When review or feedback is request on the project for the steering committee, a 2-4 week deadline is typically given to provide ample time for review and consideration.


Annual Meeting
Each year, we will hold a meeting to review:

Committee membership. We will ask if anyone is interested in stepping down from the committee and ideas for a suitable replacement.
This guidebook. We will ask the committee to review the guidebook prior to the meeting and be prepared to offer feedback on topics that should be added, edited, removed, etc.



Tools and Resources

asar repo
stockplotr repo
Workflows GitHub team
Google chat space
GitHub discussions for public and open discussion on releases, questions, and specific topics

title: Why
text:
We developed this guidebook for multiple reasons.
First, we hope that gathering important project-related information into one place will facilitate your onboarding, independence, and integration into the group. It will also act as a resource to turn to if you find yourself unsure about anything related to the team: how it functions, its origin story, etc.
Secondly, we hope that publishing this resource will increase the reproducibility of our project and decrease loss of institutional knowledge, especially since the Workflows project’s core members are contractors.

title: Why
text:
High-level, conceptual goals
In one of the project’s first documents (see the “Assessment and Workflows” section), a broad goal of the Workflows project was to “…take advantage of recent advances in technology and improve overall assessment processes”. In alignment with the 2018 Next Generation Stock Assessment Improvement Plan, our project aims to improve three of the “4Ts” of a timely, efficient, and effective stock assessment enterprise: throughput (the number of assessments that can be produced); timeliness (the speed of assessment processes and assessment product delivery), and transparency (the accessibility of assessment results). Adoption of the project’s products should also “contribute to better service and improved trust with [NSAP’s] partners and stakeholders”.
In parallel with these goals, we expect the workflow to decrease the amount of time and effort spent completing tasks manually, when they could be completed in a semi-automated fashion. This outcome should increase reproducibility and transparency in stock assessment workflows, in alignment of the NOAA Fisheries Open Science initiative.

title: Why
text:
Specific goals
To accomplish those high-level goals, we are focused on achieving the following objectives:

Developing a workflow based on two R packages that create stock assessment templates and plots
Facilitating workflow adoption by engaging in various teaching opportunities (workshops, office hours, etc.)

title: Customization
text: Quarto allow many bells and whistles to make nice output. Read the documentation here Quarto documentation.

title: Customization
text: Quarto allow many bells and whistles to make nice output. Read the documentation here Quarto documentation.

title: Customization
text:
Examples
Looking at other people’s Quarto code is a great way to figure out how to do stuff. Most will have a link to a GitHub repo where you can see the raw code. Look for a link to edit page or see source code. This will usually be on the right. Or look for the GitHub icon somewhere.

Quarto gallery
nmfs-openscapes
Fay lab manual
quarto-titlepages Note the link to edit is broken. Go to repo and look in documentation directory.

title: Who
text:
Who
Current and previous members of the workflows project team.

name <- c(
  "Sam Schiano",
  "Sophie Breitbart",
  "Steve Saul",
  "Kathryn Doering",
  "Bai Li"
  )
role <- c(
  "Coordinator and developer",
  "Developer",
  "Research & Development",
  "Coordinator",
  "Developer and Coordinator"
)
status <- c(
  "Active",
  "Active", 
  "Inactive",
  "Inactive",
  "Inactive"
)
time_zone <- c(
  "Eastern Time (US & Canada)",
  "Eastern Time (US & Canada)",
  "Mountain Time",
  "Western Time (US & Canada)",
  "Eastern Time (US & Canada)"
)
description <- c(
  "Sam is an initial team member who brainstormed and began development of the project. She primarily works on package development for {asar} and {stockplotr}, and leads interactions with the client and steering committee.",
  "Sophie is a team member who joined once the project was underway. She primarily works on package development for {asar} and {stockplotr}, especially the components that add accessibility features to the reports.",
  "Steve...",
  "Kathryn...",
  "Bai..."
)

# Note to Sam: data.table and gt need to be added to the GH action so that they're installed, or else the website won't render properly
info_df <- data.table::as.data.table(
  data.frame(
    "Name" = name,
    "Role" = role,
    "Status" = status,
    "Time Zone" = time_zone,
    "Description" = description
  )
)
# library(gt)

title: Customize
text:
Edit the qmd or md files in the content folder. qmd files can include code (R, Python, Julia) and lots of Quarto markdown bells and whistles (like call-outs, cross-references, auto-citations and much more).
Each page should start with
---
title: your title
---
and the first header will be the 2nd level, so ##. Note, there are situations where you leave off
---
title: your title
---
and start the qmd file with a level header #, but if using the default title yaml (in the --- fence) is a good habit since it makes it easy for Quarto convert your qmd file to other formats (like into a presentation).

title: Customize
text:
Add your pages the project

Add the files to _quarto.yml

title: Rendering with Code
text:
You can have code (R, Python or Julia) in your qmd file. You will need to have these installed on your local computer, but presumably you do already if you are adding code to your qmd files.
x <- c(5, 15, 25, 35, 45, 55)
y <- c(5, 20, 14, 32, 22, 38)
lm(x ~ y)


Call:
lm(formula = x ~ y)

Coefficients:
(Intercept)            y  
      1.056        1.326

title: Rendering with Code
text:
Modify the GitHub Action
You will need to change the GitHub Action in .github/workflows to install these and any needed packages in order for GitHub to be able to render your webpage. The GitHub Action install R since I used that in code.qmd. If you use Python or Julia instead, then you will need to update the GitHub Action to install those.
If getting the GitHub Action to work is too much hassle (and that definitely happens), you can alway render locally and publish to the gh-pages branch. If you do this, make sure to delete or rename the GitHub Action to something like
render-and-publish.old_yml
so GitHub does not keep trying to run it. Nothing bad will happen if you don’t do this, but if you are not using the action (because it keeps failing), then you don’t need GitHub to run it.

title: Rendering with Code
section: Render locally and publish to gh-pages branch
text:
Render locally and publish to gh-pages branch
To render locally and push up to the gh-pages branch, open a terminal window and then cd to the directory with the Quarto project. Type this in the terminal:
quarto render gh-pages

title: Acknowledgements
text: This repo and GitHub Action was based on the tutorial by Openscapes quarto-website-tutorial by Julia Lowndes and Stefanie Butland.

title: The Steering Committee
text:
The current members of the workflows steering committee are:


Ben Williams (AFSC)
Daniel Hennen (NEFSC)
Kiva Oken (NWFSC)
Eli Holmes (NWFSC)
Lisa Ailloud (SEFSC)
Caitlin Allen Akselrud (SWFSC)
Megumi Oshima (PIFSC)
Michelle Sculley (PIFSC)
Kelli Johnson (HQ OST)

Each member of the team was initially chosen for their historical involvement with reproducible workflow development for their respective regions and their expertise with stock assessments. The committee aims to represent a diverse range of perspectives from different NOAA Fisheries science centers and offices.

title: Role of the Steering Committee
text:
The workflows steering committee serves as an advisory group to provide strategic guidance, feedback, and expertise on stock assessment workflows at NOAA Fisheries. The committee’s primary role is to ensure that the development and implementation of reproducible workflows align with the needs and priorities of NOAA Fisheries science centers and offices.
The steering committee members are expected to:

Attend monthly virtual meetings to discuss project updates, challenges, and opportunities
Review and provide feedback on project plans, documentation, and deliverables
Share insights and best practices from their respective regions and areas of expertise
Advocate for the adoption of reproducible workflows within their organizations
Collaborate with the workflows team to identify and address any barriers to implementation

Please see ?@sec-membership on what a steering committee is responsible to do when they are no longer able to serve the committee.

title: Role of the Steering Committee
text:
Code of Conduct

Our Pledge
We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.
We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.


Our Standards
Examples of behavior that contributes to a positive environment for our community include:

Demonstrating empathy and kindness toward other people
Being respectful of differing opinions, viewpoints, and experiences
Giving and gracefully accepting constructive feedback
Accepting responsibility and apologizing to those affected by our mistakes, and learning from the experience
Focusing on what is best not just for us as individuals, but for the overall community

Examples of unacceptable behavior include:

The use of sexualized language or imagery, and sexual attention or advances of any kind
Trolling, insulting or derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
Public or private harassment
Publishing others’ private information, such as a physical or email address, without their explicit permission
Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting

This Code of Conduct is an abbreviated version of the asar code of conduct, which was adapted from the [Contributor Covenant][homepage], version 2.1, available at https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html.

title: Role of the Steering Committee
text:
Processes for getting involved
Steering committee members are encouraged to actively participate in discussions, provide feedback, and contribute to the development of reproducible workflows. Members can get involved by attending meetings, reviewing project materials, and engaging in discussions through email or GitHub. We also encourage steering committee members to contribute previous code that is adaptable to the project or through a “Pull Request” if they so choose.
The workflows team is actively working on adding more opportunities for steering committee members to get involved in the project through the use of detailed and actionable GitHub issues on the repositories page. Please see the stockplotr issues page or asar issues page for potential tasks if you are interested in contributing.
